conclusion: The well has depth 8 m and radius 0.5 m; the frog is at the right center of the bottom; the refractive index of water is n = 4/3; the frog wants to move up the right side of the well to see all scenery outside.
The task is to find the maximum vertical distance from the water surface where the frog can see the entire panoramic view outside the well.
Snell's law of refraction is involved: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2), where n1 = 1 (air) and n2 = 4/3 (water).
To see the entire panoramic view, the frog must be able to see light rays coming from the horizon, with the critical ray grazing the opposite edge of the well.
For the frog to see the horizon, the light ray must refract at the water surface with maximum angle when incident ray from air is nearly parallel to the water surface.
Using Snell's law: sin(theta2) = 3/4, therefore theta2 = arcsin(3/4) ≈ 48.59°.
The vertical distance from the water surface to the frog is denoted as h, forming a right triangle with vertical distance (8-h) and horizontal distance 0.5 m.
Calculate tan(theta2) = 0.5/(8-h) and solve for h using tan(arcsin(3/4)) = 3/sqrt(7).
Solve for h: 3(8-h) = 0.5 sqrt(7), resulting in h ≈ 7.56 meters.
Calculate the distance from the water surface to the frog: 8 - 7.56 = 0.44 meters.
The farthest vertical distance from the wellhead water surface where the frog can have a panoramic view is approximately 0.44 meters.
